anchor.surface_text: On September 18, 1959, the Act came into force and under s. 3 thereof a Panchayat Samithi was constituted for Chintapudi.

issues.text: whether the order of the Government dated April 18, 1963, was made under the Rules made by the Government in exercise of its power under s. 69 of the Act, rather than under ss. 62 or 72.
The order of the Government cancelling the resolution dated May 29, 1961, was made under s. 62 of the Act and, therefore, the said order could not be reviewed under s. 72 thereof.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Desai, learned counsel for the appellant, raised before us the following points 1 The order of the Government cancelling the resolution dated May 29, 1961, was made under s. 62 of the Act and, therefore, the said order could not be reviewed under s. 72 thereof.

issues.text: Assuming that the said order dated March 7, 1962, was made under s. 72(1) of the Act, the order dated April 18, 1963, reviewing the said order was invalid inasmuch as the prerequisite for the exercise of the power of review thereunder, namely, the existence of a mistake of fact or law or the ignorance of any material fact, was not satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: 2 Assuming that the said order dated March 7, 1962, was made under s. 72 1 of the Act, the order dated April 18, 1963, reviewing the said order was invalid inasmuch as the prerequisite for the exercise of the power of review thereunder, namely, the existence of a mistake of fact or law, or in ignorance of any material fact, was not satisfied.

issues.text: The order dated April 18, 1963, was also invalid, because it was made without giving an opportunity to the party prejudiced thereby of making a representation against the making of the said order.

anchor.surface_text: 3 The order dated April 18, 1963, was also invalid, because it was made without giving an opportunity to the party prejudiced thereby of making a representation against the making of the said order.

issues.text: whether the rules made under s. 69 are inconsistent with s. 18 of the Act and cannot override the statutory powers of the Panchayat Samithi.
whether in view of harmonious construction (generalia specialibus non derogant), s. 72 excludes cases under the special provision s. 62.
whether the order dated March 7, 1962 was passed without giving opportunity of explanation to the Panchayat Samithi as required under s. 62(2).
whether after exercising power under s. 62, the Government becomes functus officio and cannot review or repeatedly exercise the power.

arguments.claim: The order of the Government cancelling the resolution dated May 29, 1961, was made under s. 62 of the Act and, therefore, the said order could not be reviewed under s. 72 thereof.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Desai, learned counsel for the appellant, raised before us the following points 1 The order of the Government cancelling the resolution dated May 29, 1961, was made under s. 62 of the Act and, therefore, the said order could not be reviewed under s. 72 thereof.

arguments.court_reasoning: S.62 is special provision, general s.72 does not apply (generalia specialibus non derogant); order analysis shows it cancelled resolution under s.62.

arguments.claim: Assuming that the said order dated March 7, 1962, was made under s. 72(1) of the Act, the order dated April 18, 1963, reviewing the said order was invalid inasmuch as the prerequisite for the exercise of the power of review thereunder, namely, the existence of a mistake of fact or law or the ignorance of any material fact, was not satisfied.

anchor.surface_text: 2 Assuming that the said order dated March 7, 1962, was made under s. 72 1 of the Act, the order dated April 18, 1963, reviewing the said order was invalid inasmuch as the prerequisite for the exercise of the power of review thereunder, namely, the existence of a mistake of fact or law, or in ignorance of any material fact, was not satisfied.

arguments.claim: The order dated April 18, 1963, was also invalid, because it was made without giving an opportunity to the party prejudiced thereby of making a representation against the making of the said order.

anchor.surface_text: 3 The order dated April 18, 1963, was also invalid, because it was made without giving an opportunity to the party prejudiced thereby of making a representation against the making of the said order.

arguments.court_reasoning: Violates proviso to s.72(1); mandatory opportunity not given to prejudiced party.

arguments.court_reasoning: Appellant as President of committee, trustee of funds, representative; prejudiced; personal right includes trustee interest.

arguments.claim: The order of the Government dated March 7, 1962, was not simply a cancellation of a resolution made by the Panchayat Samithi, but a composite order giving directions to the Block Development Officer and, therefore, it fell directly within the scope of s. 72 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: lie argued that the order of the Government dated March 7, 1962, was not simply a cancella- tion of a resolution made by the Panchayat Samithi, but a composite order giving directions to the Block Development Officer and, therefore, it fell directly within the scope of s. 72 of the Act

arguments.court_reasoning: Analysis of order shows it is cancellation of resolution under s.62; preamble and reasons indicate so.

arguments.claim: As the said order was made under a misapprehension that there was a permanent location of the Health Centre at Dharmajigudem, the Government had jurisdiction to review the same under S. 72(2) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: and, as the said order was made under a misapprehension that there was a permanent location of the Health Centre at Dharmajigudem, the Government had jurisdiction to review the same under S. 72 3  of the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Order under s.62, not s.72; s.72(2) only reviews s.72(1) orders.

arguments.claim: Even if the order dated March 7, 1962, was passed under s. 62 of the Act, the said order being an administrative one, the Government had jurisdiction to review the same under s. 62 itself when the mistake was discovered.

anchor.surface_text: He would further contend that even if the order dated March 7, 1962, was passed under s. 62 of -the Act, the said order being an administrative one, the Government had jurisdiction to review the same under s. 62 itself when the mistake was discovered or brought to its notice.

arguments.court_reasoning: S.62 quasi-judicial; functus officio after order; s.13 General Clauses not apply to quasi-judicial.

arguments.claim: The impugned order was neither made under s. 62 nor under s. 72 of the Act, but under the relevant Rules made by the Government in exercise of the power conferred on it under s. 69 of the Act, read with sub-s. (2) of s. 18 thereof.
arguments.court_reasoning: Rules inconsistent with s.18 vesting power in Panchayat Samithi; rules cannot override statute.

arguments.claim: The order dated March 7, 1962 did not mention the section, did not cancel any resolution explicitly, considered other matters, and gave directions, so made in terms of s. 72.
arguments.court_reasoning: Preamble mentions resolution, reasons why invalid, concludes no valid reason to shift = cancellation under s.62.

arguments.claim: Appellant had locus standi under Art.226 as representative of committee, trustee of funds collected, prejudiced by order.

anchor.surface_text: The first question is whether the appellant had locus standi to file a petition in the High Court under Art. 226 of the Constitution. ... The appellant is the President of the Panchayat Samithi of Dharmajigudem. The villagers of Dharmajigudem formed a committee with the appellant as President

arguments.claim: Rules under s.69 inconsistent with s.18 vesting power to establish Primary Health Centres in Panchayat Samithi; cannot make it recommendatory only.
Order March 7, 1962 was under s.62 as it cancelled resolution for not having 2/3 majority.
Principle generalia specialibus non derogant: s.72 general does not apply to special s.62 cases.
S.62 quasi-judicial; after order, functus officio; no review; s.13 General Clauses not apply.
Order March 7 violated s.62(2) no opportunity to Panchayat Samithi.
There was mistake of fact in March 7 order (no permanent location), but review invalid anyway; also no notice to prejudiced party under s.72 proviso.

holdings.text: The appellant had the right to maintain the application under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, no hesitation to hold that the appellant had the right to maintain the application under Art. 226 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant as President of committee, trustee of funds collected for PHC, representative of village, prejudiced by order; personal right includes trustee interest; exceptional cases allow writ if prejudicially affected.

holdings.text: The rules made under s.69, insofar as they make the Panchayat Samithi a mere recommendatory body, are inconsistent with s.18 of the Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: S.18 vests power to establish and maintain PHC in Panchayat Samithi; rules cannot divest statutory power or vest in Govt; rule-making under s.69 cannot override statute; location integral to establishment.

holdings.text: The order dated March 7, 1962 was made under s.62 of the Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual analysis of order: preamble mentions resolution, reasons cite lack of 2/3 majority under rules (grounds under s.62), concludes no valid reason to shift = cancellation; mere absence of 'cancel' irrelevant.

holdings.text: An order under s.62 cannot be reviewed under s.72.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction: s.62 special provision for cancelling resolutions; s.72 general revision/review; generalia specialibus non derogant; s.72(2) reviews only s.72(1) orders.

holdings.text: S.62 confers quasi-judicial power; after order, Government functus officio; cannot review or repeatedly exercise under s.13 General Clauses.
holdings.reasoning_summary: S.62 requires opportunity for explanation (quasi-judicial); s.13 allows repeated administrative exercise but not quasi-judicial; no review power in s.62 unlike s.72.

holdings.text: Order dated March 7, 1962 violated s.62(2) as no opportunity given to Panchayat Samithi.
holdings.reasoning_summary: S.62(2) mandates opportunity for explanation before action under s.62(1); no notice given.

holdings.text: Order dated April 18, 1963 invalid for violating proviso to s.72(1): no opportunity to prejudiced party.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso to s.72(1) mandatory; appellant/committee representing Dharmajigudem village prejudiced, no notice given despite role throughout.

holdings.text: High Court rightly refused to quash order dated April 18, 1963 in exercise of discretion under Art.226.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, therefore, in our view, rightly refused to exercise its extraordinary discretionary power in the circumstances of the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Both govt orders illegal (March 7 violates s.62(2); April 18 cannot review s.62 order, also violates proviso); quashing April 18 would restore illegal March 7; no net gain, PHC at Lingapalem per valid Samithi resolution.

precedents.citation: The Calcutta Gas Company Proprietary Ltd. v. The State of West Bengal 1

anchor.surface_text: The Calcutta Gas Company Proprietary Ltd. v. The State of West Bengal 1 , dealing with the question of locus standi of the appellant in that case to file a petition under Art. 226 of the Constitution in the High Court, observed Article 226 companyfers a very wide power on the High Court to issue directions and writs of the nature mentioned therein for the enforcement of any of the rights companyferred by Part III or for any other purpose. It is, therefore, clear that persons other than those claiming fundamental right can also approach the companyrt seeking 1 1962 Supp. 3 S.C.R. 1, 6.

precedents.case_name: Calcutta Gas Company Proprietary Ltd. v. State of West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: Persons other than those claiming fundamental rights can approach the court under Art. 226 for enforcement of legal right; ordinarily the right must be personal or individual right of the petitioner, though relaxable in some cases like habeas corpus or quo warranto.
precedents.cited_holding: Article 226 confers a very wide power on the High Court to issue directions and writs of the nature mentioned therein for the enforcement of any of the rights conferred by Part III or for any other purpose. It is, therefore, clear that persons other than those claiming fundamental right can also approach the court seeking a relief thereunder. The Article in terms does not describe the classes of persons entitled to apply thereunder but it is implicit in the exercise of the extraordinary jurisdiction that the relief asked for must be one to enforce a legal right. The right that can be enforced under Art. 226 also shall ordinarily be the personal or individual right of the petitioner himself, though in the case of some of the writs like habeas corpus or quo warranto this rule may have to be relaxed or modified.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, therefore, in our view, rightly refused to exercise its extraordinary discretionary power in the circumstances of the case.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court rightly refused to quash Government order dated April 18, 1963 locating Primary Health Centre at Lingapalem, as quashing would restore illegal prior order dated March 7, 1962; no interference by court.
